concepts.title: Use pen not pencil in Section B

questions.text: Pencil is fine for Section B as long as your handwriting is neat.
questions.explanation: Assessors mark scanned images, not your actual paper. Pencil often scans too faint to read. Always use pen for Section B.
questions.studyTip: Pen for Section B—pencil doesn't scan well

questions.text: Assessors view scanned images of your work, so ink pen is essential for Section B.
questions.explanation: Papers are scanned, not viewed directly. Ink shows up clearly on scans, while pencil can be too faint to read accurately.
questions.studyTip: Bring a reliable pen—it's your answer's best friend

questions.text: The number of marks allocated indicates how many distinct points you need in your answer.
questions.explanation: Mark allocation guides detail level. A 3-mark question typically requires three distinct points or a well-developed explanation with multiple components.
questions.studyTip: 3 marks = 3 points. Count them.

questions.text: For a 2-mark question, one detailed sentence is usually enough.
questions.explanation: Two marks generally means you need two distinct points. One sentence rarely earns 2 marks unless it contains multiple required elements.
questions.studyTip: Count the marks, match the points

questions.text: If you need more space, write 'see additional space' and continue at the back of the booklet.
questions.explanation: You must clearly indicate when continuing in additional space so assessors know where to find the rest of your response.
questions.studyTip: Always signal where your answer continues

questions.text: The number of lines provided is a reliable guide to expected response length.
questions.explanation: Space provided indicates how much you should write, though handwriting size varies between students.
questions.studyTip: Use the space as a guide, but focus on answering completely

questions.text: Reading time should be used to identify key requirements and mentally plan Section B answers.
questions.explanation: Reading time is for strategic planning—assess questions, identify what's required, and mentally outline your responses.
questions.studyTip: Reading time = planning time. Use it wisely.

questions.text: You can start writing your Section B answers during reading time.
questions.explanation: Writing is not permitted during reading time. You can only read and think during this period.
questions.studyTip: Read and plan only—no writing during reading time

questions.text: Copying information directly from your notes sheet without adapting it will likely earn full marks.
questions.explanation: Assessors recognise memorised responses that don't address the specific question. You must adapt your knowledge to the context.
questions.studyTip: Apply your knowledge, don't just dump it

questions.text: Responses must be specifically tailored to the context and requirements of each question.
questions.explanation: Questions assess your ability to apply knowledge to specific situations, not just recall facts.
questions.studyTip: Always ask: does my answer address THIS question?

questions.text: For calculation questions worth more than one mark, you only need to show the final answer.
questions.explanation: Multi-mark calculations require working. Marks are awarded for demonstrated understanding through the steps, not just the final answer.
questions.studyTip: No working = no marks, even if the answer's right

questions.text: Showing working helps you earn partial marks even if your final answer is incorrect.
questions.explanation: Assessors can award marks for correct method and steps even if an error leads to an incorrect final answer.
questions.studyTip: Show your steps—it's your safety net

questions.text: When a question specifies units in the answer box, your answer must be in those units.
questions.explanation: If units are provided in the answer space, your numerical value must be in those units. Converting incorrectly loses marks.
questions.studyTip: Check the units required and convert if necessary

questions.text: You should always include units with your final answer, even if already printed in the answer space.
questions.explanation: Units are essential in science. Always include them to show complete understanding, unless already printed in the answer space.
questions.studyTip: Units are part of the answer—make them automatic

questions.text: Scientific notation should be used for very large or very small numbers to maintain precision.
questions.explanation: Scientific notation (e.g., 3.2 × 10⁻⁶) is appropriate for very large or small values and prevents errors with zeros.
questions.studyTip: Big or tiny numbers? Use scientific notation.

questions.text: After calculations, checking whether your answer makes sense is an important final step.
questions.explanation: A sense-check helps catch errors. Ask yourself: does this value seem reasonable for this biological context?
questions.studyTip: Sense-check every answer—does it seem biologically reasonable?

concepts.title: Lines of best fit consider all points

questions.text: A line of best fit should always pass through the first and last data points.
questions.explanation: This is wrong. Lines of best fit must consider ALL data points, distributing them roughly equally above and below the line.
questions.studyTip: Best fit ≠ connect the dots

questions.text: A proper line of best fit has roughly equal numbers of data points above and below it.
questions.explanation: The line represents the general trend, minimising overall distance to all points, not just endpoints.
questions.studyTip: Balance points above and below your line

concepts.title: Use ruler to read graphs accurately

questions.text: Using a ruler helps read values from graphs accurately.
questions.explanation: A ruler helps you read values precisely from graphs, especially when accuracy matters for subsequent calculations.
questions.studyTip: Bring a clear ruler to every exam

questions.text: Estimating values by eye is usually accurate enough for exam purposes.
questions.explanation: Visual estimation leads to errors. Using a ruler to read values accurately is essential, especially when those values affect your analysis.
questions.studyTip: Eyes lie. Rulers don't.

questions.text: When calculating gradient, select two points on the line that are far apart.
questions.explanation: Points far apart reduce percentage error and give a more accurate gradient. Both points must actually be on your drawn line.
questions.studyTip: Far apart on the line = better gradient

questions.text: When finding a gradient, you can use any two data points from the original data table.
questions.explanation: Use points on your line of best fit, not original data points. The gradient represents your fitted trend, not individual measurements.
questions.studyTip: Gradient from the LINE, not the table

questions.text: Axis scales don't need to be evenly spaced as long as all points fit on the graph.
questions.explanation: Axes must have even, regular spacing. Uneven scales distort the data and make the graph misleading.
questions.studyTip: Even spacing is non-negotiable

questions.text: Both axes must be clearly labelled with variable names and units.
questions.explanation: Clear labels with units are essential. Without them, the graph is meaningless and you'll lose marks.
questions.studyTip: Labels + units on BOTH axes

questions.text: Saying 'the value increased' is sufficient when describing a trend.
questions.explanation: You should support trend descriptions with specific values (e.g., 'increased from 2.5 to 3.5') to demonstrate careful analysis.
questions.studyTip: Trends need numbers to back them up

questions.text: Trend descriptions should include specific values and what they represent in context.
questions.explanation: Strong analysis combines trend description with specific data and explains what it means for the investigation.
questions.studyTip: Trend + values + meaning = strong analysis

questions.text: Glycolysis occurs inside the mitochondria along with other stages of cellular respiration.
questions.explanation: Glycolysis occurs in the cytosol. Only the Krebs cycle and electron transport chain occur within the mitochondria.
questions.studyTip: Cytosol = glycolysis. Mitochondria = Krebs + ETC.

questions.text: A cell without mitochondria could still produce ATP through glycolysis.
questions.explanation: Glycolysis occurs in the cytosol and produces 2 ATP without requiring mitochondria. Red blood cells lack mitochondria but still function.
questions.studyTip: No mitochondria? Glycolysis still works.

questions.text: The electron transport chain occurs on the outer mitochondrial membrane.
questions.explanation: The ETC occurs on the inner mitochondrial membrane (cristae), not the outer membrane. This is where most ATP is produced.
questions.studyTip: Inner membrane = cristae = ETC = most ATP

questions.text: The Krebs cycle occurs in the mitochondrial matrix and produces 2 ATP.
questions.explanation: The Krebs cycle takes place in the matrix (inner space) of the mitochondria and directly produces 2 ATP molecules.
questions.studyTip: Matrix = Krebs = 2 ATP. Cristae = ETC = 26-28 ATP.

questions.text: The light-dependent stage can occur in the dark if NADPH and ATP are provided.
questions.explanation: The light-dependent stage requires light energy to split water and cannot occur without light, regardless of available NADPH and ATP.
questions.studyTip: Light-dependent = needs light. It's in the name.

questions.text: The light-independent stage occurs in the stroma and doesn't directly require light.
questions.explanation: The Calvin cycle (light-independent stage) occurs in the stroma and uses NADPH and ATP from the light-dependent stage, but doesn't directly need light.
questions.studyTip: Stroma = Calvin cycle = uses products, not light directly

concepts.title: Rubisco binds both CO₂ and O₂

questions.text: Rubisco can only bind to carbon dioxide, which is why photorespiration doesn't occur at low temperatures.
questions.explanation: Rubisco can bind to both CO₂ and O₂. Photorespiration is less common at low temperatures because CO₂ is more likely to bind than O₂.
questions.studyTip: Rubisco isn't picky—it binds CO₂ AND O₂

questions.text: Photorespiration occurs when Rubisco binds to oxygen instead of carbon dioxide.
questions.explanation: When Rubisco binds O₂ rather than CO₂, photorespiration results, wasting energy and reducing photosynthetic efficiency.
questions.studyTip: O₂ binding = photorespiration = wasted energy

questions.text: Natural killer cells and cytotoxic T cells both destroy infected cells, but NK cells are part of the adaptive immune system.
questions.explanation: Natural killer cells are innate (non-specific, early response). Cytotoxic T cells are adaptive (specific, later response).
questions.studyTip: NK = innate = early. Cytotoxic T = adaptive = later.

questions.text: Both NK cells and cytotoxic T cells recognise infected cells via MHC-I markers and induce apoptosis.
questions.explanation: Both cell types target infected cells displaying antigens on MHC-I and cause cell death, though they differ in specificity and timing.
questions.studyTip: Both kill via MHC-I recognition, but differ in specificity

questions.text: Neutrophils commonly act as antigen-presenting cells by displaying antigens on MHC Class II markers.
questions.explanation: Neutrophils don't commonly present antigens. Dendritic cells, macrophages, and B cells are the professional APCs with MHC Class II.
questions.studyTip: APCs with MHC-II: dendritic cells, macrophages, B cells

questions.text: Dendritic cells phagocytose pathogens and present antigens on MHC-II to activate T helper cells.
questions.explanation: Dendritic cells engulf pathogens, then travel to lymph nodes where they present antigens on MHC-II to helper T cells, initiating adaptive response.
questions.studyTip: Dendritic cells = bridge between innate and adaptive

questions.text: Antibodies directly kill pathogens by attaching to them and destroying their cell membranes.
questions.explanation: Antibodies don't directly kill. They bind to antigens and tag them for destruction (opsonisation), neutralise them, or cause agglutination.
questions.studyTip: Antibodies tag and neutralise—they don't kill directly

questions.text: Antibodies bind to antigens, leading to agglutination, neutralisation, or opsonisation.
questions.explanation: These are the main mechanisms by which antibodies help eliminate pathogens—making them visible to immune cells or preventing their function.
questions.studyTip: Three A's of antibodies: Agglutination, (Ant)ibody neutralisation, (A)psonisation

questions.text: Eukaryotic cells use operons for gene regulation, similar to prokaryotes.
questions.explanation: Eukaryotic cells don't have operons—these are prokaryotic structures. Eukaryotes have different gene regulation mechanisms.
questions.studyTip: Operons = prokaryotes ONLY

questions.text: Eukaryotic genes have promoter and terminator sequences but lack operator regions.
questions.explanation: Operator regions are specific to prokaryotic operons. Eukaryotic genes use different regulatory mechanisms.
questions.studyTip: Operators are prokaryotic—eukaryotes regulate differently

questions.text: In CRISPR-Cas9, the single guide RNA (sgRNA) must be complementary to the target gene sequence.
questions.explanation: The sgRNA is designed to be complementary to the specific DNA sequence you want to edit, guiding Cas9 to the correct location.
questions.studyTip: sgRNA complementarity = targeting accuracy

questions.text: The PAM sequence is part of the CRISPR array in bacteria.
questions.explanation: The PAM (Protospacer Adjacent Motif) is adjacent to the target DNA, not part of the CRISPR array. Cas9 must recognise PAM to cut.
questions.studyTip: PAM is NEXT TO the target, not in the CRISPR array

questions.text: tRNA molecules carry amino acids to the ribosome, where their anticodons pair with mRNA codons.
questions.explanation: This describes the key role of tRNA—carrying amino acids and using anticodon-codon pairing to ensure correct sequence.
questions.studyTip: tRNA = amino acid delivery via anticodon-codon pairing

questions.text: Proteins are transcribed from DNA in the nucleus and translated in the cytoplasm.
questions.explanation: Genes are transcribed into mRNA, not proteins. mRNA is then translated into proteins. Use the correct terminology.
questions.studyTip: Transcription makes mRNA. Translation makes proteins.

concepts.title: C4 plants use bundle sheath cells

questions.text: C4 plants fix CO₂ in mesophyll cells, just like C3 plants.
questions.explanation: C4 plants initially fix CO₂ in mesophyll cells as a 4-carbon compound, but the Calvin cycle occurs in bundle sheath cells—unlike C3 plants.
questions.studyTip: C4 Calvin cycle = bundle sheath. C3 = mesophyll.

questions.text: C4 plants are better adapted to high temperatures because they experience less photorespiration.
questions.explanation: Bundle sheath arrangement in C4 plants means higher CO₂ concentration where Rubisco operates, reducing oxygen competition and photorespiration.
questions.studyTip: C4 = less photorespiration = better in heat

questions.text: Antigenic drift involves major sudden changes to viral surface antigens through reassortment.
questions.explanation: That describes antigenic shift. Antigenic drift involves gradual small changes through point mutations.
questions.studyTip: Drift = gradual mutations. Shift = sudden reassortment.

questions.text: Antigenic drift causes gradual changes to viral antigens that may reduce previous immunity effectiveness.
questions.explanation: Small accumulated mutations in drift mean previous antibodies are less effective, requiring updated vaccines.
questions.studyTip: Drift = why we need annual flu vaccines

questions.text: Genetic drift and natural selection both involve random changes in allele frequencies.
questions.explanation: Natural selection is non-random—advantageous alleles increase. Genetic drift IS random and more pronounced in small populations.
questions.studyTip: Drift = random. Selection = non-random advantage.

questions.text: Genetic drift causes random allele frequency changes and has greater effect in smaller populations.
questions.explanation: In small populations, chance events significantly alter allele frequencies. In large populations, chance effects are diluted.
questions.studyTip: Small population = big drift effect

questions.text: Allopatric speciation can occur when populations are in the same geographic location.
questions.explanation: Allopatric speciation requires geographic isolation. Populations in the same location would be sympatric speciation.
questions.studyTip: Allo = other place. Sym = same place.

questions.text: Geographic barriers like mountains or rivers can lead to allopatric speciation by preventing gene flow.
questions.explanation: Physical separation prevents interbreeding. Over time, isolated populations accumulate different mutations and may become reproductively isolated.
questions.studyTip: Barrier → isolation → different mutations → new species

questions.text: Homologous structures have similar function but different evolutionary origins.
questions.explanation: That describes analogous structures. Homologous structures have similar structure/origin but may have different functions (e.g., bat wing and human arm).
questions.studyTip: Homologous = same origin. Analogous = same function.

questions.text: The pentadactyl limb in vertebrates is an example of a homologous structure indicating common ancestry.
questions.explanation: The five-digit limb pattern in vertebrates (modified for different functions) shows common ancestry—same basic structure, different uses.
questions.studyTip: Pentadactyl limb = classic homology example

questions.text: A gene pool refers to all the genes of one individual in a population.
questions.explanation: A gene pool is the total collection of all alleles of all genes in an entire population, not one individual.
questions.studyTip: Gene pool = ALL alleles in the WHOLE population

questions.text: Evolution is defined as a change in allele frequencies within a population's gene pool over time.
questions.explanation: This is the biological definition of evolution—changes in how common different alleles are in the population across generations.
questions.studyTip: Evolution = allele frequency change over time

questions.text: Passive immunity provides long-lasting protection because the body produces memory cells.
questions.explanation: Passive immunity provides temporary protection—antibodies from another source. Active immunity creates memory cells for long-lasting protection.
questions.studyTip: Passive = borrowed antibodies = temporary. Active = your own = lasting.

questions.text: Vaccines provide active immunity by stimulating the body to produce its own antibodies and memory cells.
questions.explanation: Vaccines trigger an immune response, creating memory B and T cells that provide long-term protection without causing disease.
questions.studyTip: Vaccines = active immunity = memory cells = long-term

questions.text: In codominance, heterozygotes show a blended intermediate phenotype.
questions.explanation: That describes incomplete dominance. In codominance, both alleles are fully expressed—you see BOTH phenotypes, not a blend.
questions.studyTip: Codominance = BOTH show. Incomplete = blend.

questions.text: Human AB blood type demonstrates codominance because both A and B antigens are expressed.
questions.explanation: In AB blood type, both A and B alleles are fully expressed, producing both antigens—neither dominates or blends.
questions.studyTip: AB blood = classic codominance example

questions.text: Enzymes provide energy to speed up chemical reactions in cells.
questions.explanation: Enzymes don't provide energy. They lower the activation energy required, making it easier for reactions to proceed.
questions.studyTip: Enzymes LOWER the barrier—they don't add energy

questions.text: Enzymes lower the activation energy required for a chemical reaction to occur.
questions.explanation: This is exactly what enzymes do—reduce the energy barrier so reactions proceed more easily at body temperature.
questions.studyTip: Enzymes = lower activation energy = faster reactions

questions.text: When environments change, organisms adapt during their lifetime and pass these adaptations to offspring.
questions.explanation: This is Lamarckian thinking and incorrect. Evolution occurs through natural selection of existing genetic variation, not acquired characteristics.
questions.studyTip: Acquired traits aren't inherited—Lamarck was wrong

questions.text: Natural selection favours individuals with advantageous alleles, increasing their frequency in future generations.
questions.explanation: This is correct—existing beneficial variations are selected for, not acquired during life.
questions.studyTip: Selection acts on existing variation, not acquired traits

questions.text: Mitochondria provide ATP to cells as an energy source.
questions.explanation: This phrasing is imprecise. Mitochondria PRODUCE ATP through cellular respiration—they don't simply 'provide' it as if stored there.
questions.studyTip: Be precise: mitochondria PRODUCE ATP through respiration

questions.text: Mitochondria produce ATP through the process of cellular respiration.
questions.explanation: This is the accurate description—mitochondria are where cellular respiration produces ATP from glucose and oxygen.
questions.studyTip: Precise terminology matters in biology

questions.text: Immune cells destroy pathogens directly by targeting and killing bacteria or viruses.
questions.explanation: This oversimplifies. Phagocytes engulf pathogens, but cytotoxic T cells and NK cells kill infected HOST cells, not pathogens directly.
questions.studyTip: Phagocytes eat pathogens. T cells kill infected CELLS.

questions.text: Cytotoxic T cells recognise and induce apoptosis in infected host cells, not pathogens directly.
questions.explanation: Cytotoxic T cells target infected host cells displaying foreign antigens on MHC-I, causing those cells to undergo programmed death.
questions.studyTip: T cells kill infected cells, not free-floating pathogens

questions.text: During transcription, amino acids are joined together to form a polypeptide chain.
questions.explanation: That's translation, not transcription. Transcription produces mRNA from a DNA template. Translation produces protein from mRNA.
questions.studyTip: Transcription = DNA → mRNA. Translation = mRNA → protein.

questions.text: Transcription occurs in the nucleus and produces mRNA from a DNA template.
questions.explanation: Transcription is the first step of gene expression—RNA polymerase creates mRNA complementary to the DNA template strand.
questions.studyTip: Transcription = copying DNA to mRNA in the nucleus

questions.text: In DNA replication, both strands of the original double helix end up in the same new molecule.
questions.explanation: DNA replication is semi-conservative—each new molecule contains one original strand and one newly synthesised strand.
questions.studyTip: Semi-conservative = half old, half new in each molecule

questions.text: Each new DNA molecule after replication contains one original strand and one new strand.
questions.explanation: This describes semi-conservative replication, proven by the Meselson-Stahl experiment using heavy nitrogen isotopes.
questions.studyTip: Meselson-Stahl proved semi-conservative replication

questions.text: Plants only photosynthesise—they don't carry out cellular respiration like animals do.
questions.explanation: Plants do BOTH. They photosynthesise when light is available AND respire continuously to release energy from glucose.
questions.studyTip: Plants photosynthesise AND respire—both processes occur

questions.text: Plants carry out cellular respiration continuously, while photosynthesis only occurs in light.
questions.explanation: Respiration happens 24/7 in plant cells. Photosynthesis requires light and only occurs in chloroplasts when illuminated.
questions.studyTip: Respiration = always. Photosynthesis = light only.

questions.text: All mutations are harmful because they change the normal DNA sequence.
questions.explanation: Mutations can be beneficial, neutral, or harmful. Many mutations have no effect (silent), and some provide advantages.
questions.studyTip: Mutations: some bad, some good, most neutral

questions.text: Mutations provide the raw material for evolution by creating new alleles in a population.
questions.explanation: Without mutations, there would be no new genetic variation. Mutations are the ultimate source of all genetic diversity.
questions.studyTip: No mutations = no new alleles = no evolution

questions.text: When asked to 'compare', you only need to describe both items separately.
questions.explanation: 'Compare' requires identifying similarities AND differences, not just describing each item. You must make explicit comparisons.
questions.studyTip: Compare = similarities AND differences explicitly

questions.text: A good comparison addresses both items and highlights how they are similar or different.
questions.explanation: Strong comparisons reference both items and make relationships clear through explicit statements of similarities and differences.
questions.studyTip: Mention BOTH items and state the relationship

questions.text: When asked to 'explain', repeating information from the question demonstrates understanding.
questions.explanation: Restating the question shows nothing. You must add biological knowledge, mechanisms, or reasoning beyond what's given.
questions.studyTip: Explain = add new information showing WHY or HOW

questions.text: To properly explain, you should describe the mechanisms or reasoning that make something work.
questions.explanation: Explanations demonstrate understanding by describing how or why something happens, including relevant biological processes.
questions.studyTip: Does your explanation show HOW or WHY?

questions.text: When analysing graphs, stating specific values and what they represent is more effective than general descriptions.
questions.explanation: Specific data with context (e.g., '3.5 mg/g chlorophyll') is far more convincing than vague statements like 'the value was higher'.
questions.studyTip: Always include specific values with context

questions.text: Saying 'the graph shows a value of 3.5' is sufficient analysis without explaining what 3.5 represents.
questions.explanation: Numbers alone are meaningless. You must explain what they represent in the biological context of the investigation.
questions.studyTip: Numbers need meaning—what does 3.5 represent?

questions.text: For questions with multiple parts like 'describe X and explain Y', addressing only one part can earn full marks if detailed enough.
questions.explanation: You must address ALL parts. Assessors check for each component specifically and award marks accordingly.
questions.studyTip: Highlight each part before answering—don't miss any

questions.text: Dot points can help ensure you address all components of a multi-part question.
questions.explanation: Dot points organise your thoughts and ensure you cover each required element. This format is acceptable in biology exams.
questions.studyTip: Dot points = organised answers = no missed parts

questions.text: If you encounter unfamiliar terminology in multiple choice, you should guess randomly.
questions.explanation: Use elimination—rule out options you know are wrong. You can often find the answer by eliminating incorrect choices.
questions.studyTip: Eliminate wrong answers first, then choose

questions.text: Process of elimination is effective even when you don't recognise all the terms in a question.
questions.explanation: Even with unfamiliar terms, you can often eliminate wrong answers using related knowledge, increasing your odds considerably.
questions.studyTip: Can't be certain? Eliminate what you CAN rule out

concepts.title: Define key terms in extended responses

questions.text: In extended response questions, you should assume the assessor knows all the technical terms you use.
questions.explanation: Briefly defining or explaining key terms demonstrates your understanding and ensures assessors can follow your reasoning.
questions.studyTip: Define key terms—show you know what they mean

questions.text: Defining technical terms in your answer demonstrates understanding of the underlying concepts.
questions.explanation: Using terms correctly AND showing you understand them earns more marks than just dropping terminology without context.
questions.studyTip: Use terms correctly AND show you understand them

questions.text: Stating that two things are related is sufficient without explaining how they connect.
questions.explanation: You must show the mechanism—HOW one thing leads to another. Correlation isn't enough; show causation.
questions.studyTip: Show the chain: A causes B because...

questions.text: Strong answers show the causal chain connecting biological events or processes.
questions.explanation: Linking cause to effect demonstrates deep understanding. Show each step in the chain, not just the start and end points.
questions.studyTip: Connect the dots—show each step in the chain

questions.text: If you know a lot about a topic, you should include all that information regardless of what the question asks.
questions.explanation: Answer ONLY what's asked. Irrelevant information wastes time, may confuse assessors, and suggests you don't understand the question.
questions.studyTip: Answer the question asked, not the question you wish was asked

questions.text: Underlining key words in questions helps ensure you address exactly what is required.
questions.explanation: Identifying command words (describe, explain, compare) and key concepts helps you focus your response appropriately.
questions.studyTip: Underline command words and key concepts before writing
